channel.title: PreXep's PHP TuT 1 Beginner
channel.description:
First off my name stands for Pre (PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor) Xe (Expert) P (Programmer or Person). Mustly its like Preprocessor Expert Programmer. But now to the tutorial. Do not steal my name I thought long and hard making it up so keep off. --------------- I have worte this tutorial by myself. Do not take this as your own work. I put my time and knowledge into making this. So please respect it and let me take my own work into my own hand. --------------- In this tutorial I will go through the basic's about PHP.
PHP stands for Personal Home Page. Created by Rasmus Lerdorf. It is now known as PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor today. PHP is a server side scripting langauge. PHP is writen in .php but can also be written in other files as .html, .htm, .asp, and sometimes your own extension files. But will get into those in master Tutorials.
[size=25pt]Enable PHP[/size] There are 4 different ways to enable PHP. But some must be set to be enabled in the php.ini. But will worry about setting them later. We just need to know what they are first.
The must commonly used: [code=php] <?php //PHP Code Here ?>[/code]
A short_open_tag must be enabled by 1 in the php.ini. It is by default so know worrys. It is the same as the one above just without the php. [code=php] <? //PHP Code Here ?>[/code]
Another one is proble one you seen working with JS or something. [code=php] <script language="php"> //PHP Code Here </script>[/code]
Last but not least is the ASP_Tag. This is turned off by default. It is to enable PHP in ASP files. [code=php] <% //PHP Code Here %>[/code] [hr] [size=25pt]Hello World![/size] The next step of beginning to learn PHP is how to make text. What would you do with out it? There are 3 ways to make text. The 2 PHP functions and the Escaping PHP and useing HTML to do it.
First and must commonly used is the echo() function to print text. There are a few different ways to write the function with bracets and what not. [code=php] <?php echo("Hello World!"); //With bracets echo('Hello World!'); //With bracets but use ' ' echo "Hello World!"; //Without bracets echo 'Hello World!'; //Withour bracets but use ' ' echo hello_world; //One word don't need bracets or quotes but can't use spaces or reports error. ?>[/code] Prints out Exactly: Hello World!Hello World!Hello World!Hello World!hello_world
HTML will work in the echo() function. Example: [code=php]<?php echo "Welcome, <font color='red'>Guest!</font>"; ?>[/code] Prints out: Welcome, Guest! ---------------------------------- Another writing text function is print(). This is the same thing as echo() but just a different name. It does the same thing as the echo() function. So I don't think I need to show the same examples for it. [hr] [size=25pt]Variable[/size] Variables is one name containing another source of data. A variable is represented by a $. Varaible is case-sensitive.
Setting a variable is easy. Example below. [code=php]<?php $hello="Hello World!"; print $hello; //Prints out the Varaible ?>[/code] Prints out: Hello World!
You can also print() or echo() out more then one varaible in the same print() or echo() function.
You can do many more things with a variable but will get into them in another tutorial. [hr] [size=25pt]CONSTANTS[/size] A constant is like a variable but the whole thing is caped and oes not use a $. It also cant be presented with quotes in a print or echo function. Example how it works below.
[code=php] <?php
define("HELLO", "Hello World!");
echo HELLO; echo constant("HELLO"); // same thing as the previous line
?> [/code] Nothing to big about a constant. I'd rather use a varaible. More possiblitys. [hr] [size=25pt]If, elseif, else[/size] The if, elseif, else are just true and false statements. If the if is not true it will go to elseif if its not true it will go to the else. Or you can just have If and else. If if is not ture it will go to else. Examples:
if, elseif, else example: [code=php] <?php $name='John'; if($name=='Read') echo 'Hello Read'; //Prints out Hello Read if $name equals Read elseif($name=='Mark') echo 'Hello Mark'; //Prints out Hello Mark if $name equals Mark else echo 'Hello Guest!'; ?>[/code] prints out: Hello Guest!
It prints out Hello Guest! because none of the if or elseif equals the $name. If it did it would print out the code below it. If you have more then 1 line of what the code is going to do you will need bracets. Example:
[code=php]<?php if() { //All code Here for if() } elseif() { //All code Here for elseif() } else { //All code Here for else } ?>[/code]
REMEMBER! You do not have to have the elseif or else but you must have if(). If you just have if() and its not true it does nothing but if you have if() and else and if() is not true it will do the else statement.
